column2: The contribution of the sectors covered by the EU ETS with respect to the EU Climate ambition should be of -62 % compared to 2005
column5: The implementation of TA2.11 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.12, as reducing greenhouse gas emissions can help mitigate climate change, which is a key factor in preserving biodiversity and promoting sustainable agriculture.

column2: The contribution of the sectors covered by the EU ETS with respect to the EU Climate ambition should be of -62 % compared to 2005
column5: On the other hand, the implementation of TA2.11 may have a negative impact on TA5.13, as the increased cost of reducing emissions could lead to higher food prices, making it more challenging to reduce food waste.

column2: The amount of renewable fuels and renewable electricity supplied to the transport sector leads to a: (i) share of renewable energy within the final consumption of energy in the transport sector of at least 29 % by 2030
column3: or (ii) GHG intensity reduction of at least 14.5 % by 2030
column6: The implementation of TA2.13 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.20, as increasing the share of renewable energy in the transport sector can help reduce the EU's dependence on fossil fuels and promote a more sustainable trade balance.

column2: Each Member State shall increase the share of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector by at least 0.8 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the period 2021 to 2025 and by at least 1.1 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the period 2026 to 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.14 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.21, as increasing the share of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector can help promote digitalization and improve energy efficiency, which can in turn support the development of sustainable and competitive industries.

column2: By 2022, achieve 18% of the total increase in the share of energy from renewable sources between that Member State’s binding 2020 national target, and its contribution to the 2030 target of the share of energy from renewable sources in gross final consumption of energy.
column5: The implementation of TA2.15 may have a negative impact on TA5.22, as the focus on increasing the share of renewable energy may lead to a decrease in the production and trade of other energy sources, potentially disrupting supply chains and impacting the competitiveness of certain industries.

column2: Member States shall endeavour to increase the share of renewable sources in the amount of energy sources used for final energy and non-energy purposes in the industry sector by an indicative increase of at least 1.6 percentage points as an annual average calculated for the periods 2021 to 2025 and 2026 to 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.16 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.23, as increasing the share of renewable energy in the industry sector can help reduce greenhouse gas emissions and promote sustainable employment, which can in turn support the development of a more competitive and resilient economy.

column2: A target of 15% electricity interconnection for 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.17 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.24, as increasing electricity interconnection can help promote social protection and fair employment, by providing access to a more diverse and reliable energy supply, which can support the development of sustainable and competitive industries.

column2: Indicative target of at least a 49% share of energy from renewable sources in the building sector in the Union’s final energy consumption in buildings in 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.18 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.25, as increasing the share of renewable energy in the building sector can help promote animal welfare, by reducing the environmental impact of energy production and consumption, which can support the development of sustainable and competitive industries.

column2: Member States shall ensure that the total final energy consumption of all public bodies combined is reduced by at least 1.9% each year, when compared to 2021
column5: The implementation of TA2.21 may have a negative impact on TA5.26, as reducing energy consumption in public bodies may lead to a decrease in the production and trade of energy-related products, potentially disrupting supply chains and impacting the competitiveness of certain industries.

column2: Member States shall collectively ensure a reduction of energy consumption of at least 11.7% in 2030 compared to the projections of the 2020 EU Reference Scenario
column5: The implementation of TA2.22 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.27, as reducing energy consumption can help promote food availability, by reducing the environmental impact of energy production and consumption, which can support the development of sustainable and competitive industries.

column2: Member States shall make efforts to collectively contribute to the indicative Union primary energy consumption target amounting to no more than 992.5 Mtoe in 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.23 may have a negative impact on TA5.28, as reducing primary energy consumption may lead to a decrease in the production and trade of energy-related products, potentially disrupting supply chains and impacting the competitiveness of certain industries.

column2: Each Member State shall ensure that at least 3% of the total floor area of heated and/or cooled buildings that are owned by public bodies is renovated each year to be transformed into at least nearly zero-energy buildings or zero-emission buildings
column5: The implementation of TA2.24 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.29, as renovating public buildings can help promote food availability, by reducing energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions, which can support the development of sustainable and competitive industries.

column2: Reduce buildings’ final energy consumption by 14%
column5: The implementation of TA2.25 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.30, as reducing final energy consumption in buildings can help promote food affordability, by reducing energy costs and greenhouse gas emissions, which can support the development of sustainable and competitive industries.

column2: At least double the annual energy renovation rate of residential and non-residential buildings by 2030 and to foster deep energy renovations
column5: The implementation of TA2.26 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.31, as increasing the energy renovation rate can help promote food affordability, by reducing energy costs and greenhouse gas emissions, which can support the development of sustainable and competitive industries.

column2: Reduce buildings’ energy consumption for heating and cooling by 18% compared to 2015 levels by 2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.28 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.32, as reducing energy consumption for heating and cooling can help promote food affordability, by reducing energy costs and greenhouse gas emissions, which can support the development of sustainable and competitive industries.

column2: Member states will have to renovate 16% of worst-performing non-residential buildings by 2030 and, by 2033, the worst-performing 26% through minimum energy performance requirements
column5: The implementation of TA2.29 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.33, as renovating worst-performing buildings can help promote food affordability, by reducing energy costs and greenhouse gas emissions, which can support the development of sustainable and competitive industries.

column2: The national measures will have to ensure that at least 55% of the decrease of the average primary energy use is achieved through the renovation of the worst-performing buildings
column5: The implementation of TA2.33 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.34, as renovating worst-performing buildings can help promote food affordability, by reducing energy costs and greenhouse gas emissions, which can support the development of sustainable and competitive industries.

column2: Member States shall ensure that the average primary energy use of the entire residential building stock decreases by at least 16% compared to 2020 by 2030
column3: and by at least 20-22% compared to 2020 by 2035
column6: The implementation of TA2.34 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.35, as reducing primary energy use in residential buildings can help promote food affordability, by reducing energy costs and greenhouse gas emissions, which can support the development of sustainable and competitive industries.

column2: Member States are required to achieve cumulative end-use energy savings from 2021 to 2030, equivalent to new annual savings of at least 0.8% of final energy consumption in 2021-2023, at least 1.3% in 2024-2025, 1.5% in 2026-2027 and 1.9% in 2028-2030
column5: The implementation of TA2.41 is likely to have a positive impact on TA5.36, as achieving cumulative end-use energy savings can help promote food affordability, by reducing energy costs and greenhouse gas emissions, which can support the development of sustainable and competitive industries.

column2: Genetic biodiversity of food production systems: Secure and ensure access to a range of quality seeds for plant varieties in order to adapt to the pressures of climate change.
column5: The implementation of TA5.12 may have a negative impact on TA2.11, as promoting genetic biodiversity in food production systems may require the use of more land and resources, potentially leading to increased greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Reduce food waste
column6: The implementation of TA5.13 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.13, as reducing food waste can help increase the share of renewable energy in the transport sector, by reducing the energy required for food production and transportation.

column2: Circular economy: Scale-up and promote sustainable and socially responsible production methods and circular business models in food processing and retail.
column5: The implementation of TA5.14 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.14, as promoting circular economy practices in food processing and retail can help increase the share of renewable energy in the heating and cooling sector, by reducing waste and promoting energy-efficient production methods.

column2: Consumption footprint: Reduce the environmental and climate footprint of the EU food system, operating within planetary boundaries.
column5: The implementation of TA5.15 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.15, as reducing the environmental and climate footprint of the EU food system can help achieve the target of 18% increase in the share of energy from renewable sources by 2022.

column2: Income distribution: Ensure fair income and salaries.
column5: The implementation of TA5.16 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.16, as ensuring fair income and salaries can help increase the share of renewable sources in the industry sector, by promoting sustainable and equitable economic growth.

column2: Sectorial growth: Help farmers and fishers to strengthen their position in the supply chain and to capture a fair share of the added value of sustainable production.
column5: The implementation of TA5.17 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.17, as helping farmers and fishers to strengthen their position in the supply chain can help achieve the target of 15% electricity interconnection by 2030, by promoting sustainable and resilient food systems.

column2: Market power and business structure: Improve agricultural rules that strengthen the position of farmers (e.g. producers of products with geographical indications), their cooperatives and producer organisations in the food supply chain.
column5: The implementation of TA5.18 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.18, as improving agricultural rules can help increase the share of renewable energy in the building sector, by promoting sustainable and equitable economic growth.

column2: Price: Preserve the price affordability of food.
column5: The implementation of TA5.19 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.21, as preserving the price affordability of food can help reduce energy consumption in public bodies, by promoting sustainable and equitable economic growth.

column2: Trade: Foster the competitiveness of the EU supply sector.
column5: The implementation of TA5.20 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.22, as fostering the competitiveness of the EU supply sector can help reduce energy consumption, by promoting sustainable and efficient production methods.

column2: Digitalisation and knowledge transfer. Ensure access to fast broadband to all farmers and all rural areas to achieve the objective of 100% access by 2025
column5: The implementation of TA5.21 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.23, as ensuring access to fast broadband can help reduce primary energy consumption, by promoting sustainable and efficient production methods.

column2: Transport, accessibility and infrastructure: Create shorter supply chains will support reducing dependence on long-haul transportation.
column5: The implementation of TA5.22 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.24, as creating shorter supply chains can help reduce energy consumption in buildings, by promoting sustainable and efficient production methods.

column2: Employment and working conditions: Create new job opportunities.
column5: The implementation of TA5.23 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.25, as creating new job opportunities can help reduce buildings' final energy consumption, by promoting sustainable and equitable economic growth.

column2: Social protection and poverty: Ensure fair, inclusive and ethical value chains.
column5: The implementation of TA5.24 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.26, as ensuring fair and inclusive value chains can help increase the annual energy renovation rate of residential and non-residential buildings, by promoting sustainable and equitable economic growth.

column2: Animal welfare: Promote better animal welfare to improve animal health and food quality.
column5: The implementation of TA5.25 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.28, as promoting better animal welfare can help reduce buildings' energy consumption for heating and cooling, by promoting sustainable and efficient production methods.

column2: Food messaging: Provide food information and labelling to empower consumers to make informed, healthy and sustainable food choices.
column5: The implementation of TA5.27 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.29, as providing food information and labelling can help renovate worst-performing non-residential buildings, by promoting sustainable and efficient production methods.

column2: Food availability: Improve availability of sustainable food.
column5: The implementation of TA5.29 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.33, as improving availability of sustainable food can help reduce primary energy use, by promoting sustainable and efficient production methods.

column2: Food affordability: Ensure affordability to sufficient, nutritious and sustainable food.
column5: The implementation of TA5.30 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.34, as ensuring affordability of sustainable food can help reduce primary energy use, by promoting sustainable and efficient production methods.

column2: Properties of food: Increase reformulation of food products in line with guidelines for healthy and sustainable diets.
column5: The implementation of TA5.31 is likely to have a positive impact on TA2.41, as increasing reformulation of food products can help achieve cumulative end-use energy savings, by promoting sustainable and efficient production methods.
